measured_by: preference in the coalesced choice between dominated Gamble − and dominating Gamble +
justification: "68% of participants violated dominance in the − vs. + choice" – the proportion of choices for the dominated gamble is taken as the measure of violating stochastic dominance.

measured_by: preference in the canonically split choice between GS− and GS+
justification: "18% violation rate in the split form of the same choice, − vs. +…" – low violations in the split (GS− vs GS+) choice serve to assess whether outcome monotonicity is respected.

measured_by: number of toggles between split and coalesced representations during the animation
justification: "During training, participants toggled between the split and coalesced forms of the gambles an average of 7.34 times…each additional toggle…associated with a 1.8% decrease in violation likelihood" – the count of toggles is used as an index of how much participants engaged with the training.

measured_by: reaction time for each gamble‐choice decision
justification: "Participants who satisfied stochastic dominance tended to have longer reaction times, possibly reflecting greater care, more attention, or more thought" – response latency is treated as an indicator of cognitive effort.
